For Charleston, S.C.'s hometown newspaper, the Post and Courier, it has been a very intense three months.

More than two weeks ago, unsettling signals started coming across the Post and Courier's scanner.

All units responding - 110 Calhoun Street.
Tony Bartelme, a 30-year veteran, headed to the hospital.
He met the grandson of one of the victims outside.

The last few months have been an emotional ride for everyone at the Post and Courier.
In April, they won a Pulitzer Prize for coverage of domestic violence.

They built a database of every police shooting in the state.

Journalists who cover highly traumatic events are as vulnerable to psychological injury as police officers or EMTs or firefighters.

He says the trauma is doubly hard for local reporters, who are part of the community and don't get to leave the story behind.
They are grieving at the same time they're reporting.
Now, this can be a powerful source of mission, but it also can bring real stress.
